UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA
DEPARTMENT OF ANTHROPOLOGY
LOS ANGELES 24, CALIFORNIA
July 30, 1953
AIR MIL
Mr* George E* Probst
Radio Office
University of Chicago
Chicago 373 Illinois
Dear George:
You have asked me for advice on continuation of radio programs in
the field of anthropology for the coming year—while I am on safari in
Africa* It is not easy to know where to begin, for my two years5 ex¬
perience has given me many feelings and attitudes that are difficult
to summarise, but I will try to record a few impressions that seem to
me worth passing along at this point*
Let me say that my first lesson has been that there is no sub¬
stitution for talent. If you are to continue—especially with the title
to which my name is now associated—be certain to get people who have
real talent, especially writers and the producer,, I have worked with
several writers and I Imox-r the difference it makes whether the person has
real ability or not* Two things are important: a sensitivity to the
English language as an instrument of communication and as a medium for
art; and a sensitivity for culture patterns and attitudes foreign to
those that are his own* You will find the two go together. It makes
far less difference if the writer knows anything about anthropology as
a subject so long as you have a proper anthropologist to monitor that
aspect•
This raises a crucial question: who might replace me? The cul¬
tural demands of modesty make me reluctant to assert any special talent
for myself, but I feel that certain qualities have been important in the
success of the f%ay3 of Mankind*n The first important item is that he
knows what he wants to say. A second is that he be able to work with
writers. With this some rules emerge, and I feel that despite certain
lapses I was on the whole successful. The first rule is that the an¬
thropologist be able to command the respect of able writers. This
means that he must not only have competence in his own field and Intel”
lectual honesty, but also a measure of breadth of interest and ability.
